title.narrative: Responsible practices in the ASM Peruvian and Colombian gold sectors

description.narrative:
In Peru and Colombia, we want to integrate and formalize Artisanal and Small-scale Miners (ASM), into the formal gold value chain by working with Large Scale Mines (LSM). In 2020 we have developed new partnerships with 2 large scale and industrial mining companies with 450 artisanal miners operating within their concessions. The Covid-19 crisis limited our ability to work with all mines we had foreseen for 2020. One LSM partner needed to prioritize controlling the Covid-19 infections within its own operations in order to avoid shutdown, and we could re-engage only in December. The start-up activities with a third LSM partner were delayed because of the restrictions and we can start with the first visits only in July. Yet we were able to work with one LSM, integrating 90 artisanal miners from 8 ASM groups into its concession. The benefits of this model are starting to show: material and input costs for small scale miners reduced by 25%, ore transportation time reduced by 30% and the use of mercury reduced with 36.8kgs in 2020. We made a start with the development of the first financial product specifically for ASM in Peru.
Red Social joined us to develop an initiative to study and alleviate Covid-19 effects among Pallaqueras (women miners): the Pallaqueras’ assistance platform (read more here). Through this platform we raised funds (over US$11,000) and distributed food supplies to 560 families in Arequipa, Puno and Ayacucho (Peru). We offered a remote capacity building program to adjust their work practices, daily social activities and family routines to the Covid-19 scenario. And we set up a call center that provides timely information on how to prevent and handle Covid-19 infections. In Colombia, the Covid-19 restrictions also delayed the process of building new partnerships, but from September onwards we could finalize new partnerships to provide technical and formalization assistance for 35 artisanal miners, organized in 7 ASM groups.
Together with local and international CSO partners and public authorities we developed safety protocols and booklets for the ASM sector to cope with the Covid-19 crisis (“MAPE sin Covid-19” -ASM without Covid-19- in Peru and Colombia).

comment.narrative: We have established a very interesting relationship between Solidaridad and UNDP's planetGOLD project, in which we seek to develop knowledge on access to credit for ASM. By the end of the project, we will have much more information about the functioning of an access to finance model that uses processing plants as intermediaries

comment.narrative: Minera San Luis and Minera Yanaquihua

title.narrative: # of producers with improved income as a result of the project

comment.narrative: The mine San Luis (approximately 144 associacted miners and approximately 50 workers) were supported through a series of training and assessments conducted by Solidaridad and with partner la Alianza por la Miner������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������a Responsable (ARM) to achieve certification and implementation of new technology to increase production. Through increase of production it can be concluded that miners have increased their income. The mine has not started to sell the certified responsable gold yet. The combination of these activities is expected to generate an income increase of 40% in 2019.

comment.narrative: Minera Yanaquiha, Minera San Luis, Hoschild Mining (CMA)

title.narrative: # of producers with improved income as a result of the project

comment.narrative: Asociaci������������������������������������������������������n de Mineros Artesanales Pepas de Oro de Pampamarca (AMAPOP) has dramatically increased their production from 3kg gold / month (working with 80 miners), pre Solidaridad?s intervention to up to 20 kg gold / month (working with 260 miners), post Solidaridad?s intervention doubling their per capita production. However, it is important to note that this increase is also due to the fact that the ASMO found a very generous gold vein in their operations. Nonetheless, due to their strengthened organisational capacities, they?ve been able to better organise themselves and to increase their labour production under safer practices.

title.narrative: # volume commodity sourced that meet national, international or sector specific sustainability standards or Good Practices

comment.narrative: [KPI Acumulativo] Annual production San Luis mine (96kg), certified fairmined + Annual production Yanaquihua from ASM (1,000kg) + Annual production from ASM Asoc. Pepas de Oro de Pampamarca (29kg) CMA: Initially we had an agreement that CMA would buy from ASMOs which would generate 104 kilos of responsible gold bought by CMA. However, the agreement has since changed with now the approach focused in CMA providing direct support to ASMO Pepas de Oro in their formalization process.

title.narrative: # of local SMEs (m/f/youth-operated) supported with skills, funds, and advice

comment.narrative: We brought one service provider (Zamnor, an organisational coaching agency specialised on smallholders) into the ASM sector, through our current project with CMA and Asociaci������������������������������������������������������n de Mineros Artesanales Pepas de Oro de Pampamarca (AMAPOP). Solidaridad helped Zamnor to understand the ASM sector dynamics to inform development of workshop materials and effective ways to engage with ASM participants which were a new audience for Zamnor. Currently Zamnor is also working with MACDESA, another small-scale mine located in the nearby region of Arequipa.

title.narrative: Robust Infrastructure - Producers have improved access
# farmers/miners (m/f) that obtain services by strengthened service providers

comment.narrative: Currently, after working with AMAPOP (266 miners in total), Zamnor is also working with MACDESA, a Fairmined certified mine located in the nearby region of Arequipa, comprised of 85 men and 6 women. The later number we haven't been so included as our involvement was minimal in this intervention.

title.narrative: # farmers/miners (m/f) that obtain services by strengthened service providers

comment.narrative: At this current stage it is very difficult to establish a target for the amount of miners that will benefit from improved service provider knowledge (identified in rows 35 & 36). A way to identify the amount of producers that could benefit will be part of plans in 2020. However, we could expect to work with at least one service provider in the peruvian mid-south and at least one in the peruvian north.
